message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse and uterine fibroids. The smooth texture and the feeling of heaviness may indicate the presence of uterine fibroids, which are characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium. A is the characteristic feature of endometriosis, C is not a pathological feature of any commonly seen conditions in this scenario, and D is a feature of endometrial cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse and uterine fibroids. The palpable uterus and boggy smooth texture suggest leiomyoma, which is a benign tumor of the uterus composed of smooth muscle cells and fibrous connective tissue. The classic pathological feature of leiomyoma is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest uterine prolapse or pelvic organ prolapse, and the uterine fundus palpated just above the pubic symphysis is typical of this diagnosis. Among the options, only the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium is a classic pathological feature of adenomyosis, which commonly occurs in patients with uterine prolapse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest uterine prolapse or leiomyoma. The boggy, smooth texture of the uterus suggests leiomyoma, which is a benign tumor of smooth muscle origin, and a classic pathological feature is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest she has uterine fibroids, which have a boggy, smooth texture and can cause a feeling of pelvic heaviness. A classic pathological feature of uterine fibroids is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, also known as intramural fibroids (option B). Options A, C, and D are not associated with uterine fibroids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a diagnosis of uterine fibroids, which are noncancerous growths in the uterus. The classic pathological feature of uterine fibroids is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, as they arise from the smooth muscle cells in the uterus. Presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus would suggest endometriosis, which has different symptoms. Focal hyperplasia of the myometrium and nuclear atypia of endometrial cells are not associated with uterine fibroids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms (urinary incontinence, cramping, pelvic heaviness) and physical exam findings (boggy, smooth uterus) suggest a diagnosis of uterine prolapse. The classic pathological feature of this condition is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium. Option A describes endometriosis, option C describes leiomyoma, and option D describes endometrial cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest uterine fibroids, and the boggy, smooth texture of the uterus supports this diagnosis. The classic pathological feature of uterine fibroids is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium. Option A describes endometriosis, option C describes adenomyosis, and option D describes endometrial cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and exam findings are suggestive of uterine fibroids, which commonly present with pelvic pressure or pain, heavy menstrual bleeding, and urinary incontinence. The classic pathological feature of fibroids is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, leading to a boggy, smooth texture of the uterus. Option A describes endometriosis, option C describes adenomyosis, and option D describes endometrial cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and exam findings suggest uterine fibroids, which are non-cancerous growths within the myometrium. Option A describes endometriosis, option C describes adenomyosis, and option D describes endometrial cancer, which are all less likely considering the patient's presentation.
